awd_titl_txt: CIVIC-PG Track A: Machine Learning Approaches to Improve Resilience of Water Utilities to Extreme Weather Events
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this Civic Innovation Challenge (CIVIC) project is to support research on design and implementation of a machine learning (ML)-based system, called WAUTO (Water operations AUTOmation), to optimize wastewater treatment plant operations during extreme weather events. Working with the Little Patuxent Wastewater Reclamation Plant (LPWRP), researchers from the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory (APL) and the Whiting School of Engineering (WSE) aim to enhance LPWRP’s resilience to extreme weather. Climate change is resulting in more frequent floods with higher water levels than what current models predict. In Howard County, MD, two floods, each expected to occur only every 1,000 years, took place within two years. The challenges faced by LPWRP are common nationwide. Smaller facilities, usually serving economically disadvantaged and marginalized communities, are especially vulnerable to flooding events. The WAUTO intends to enable continued system operation essential to public health and prosperity throughout the disaster. A wide range of stakeholders are engaged, including engineers, plant managers, and government officials. Success of this project could pave the way for the deployment of cutting-edge ML-based solutions for protecting critical infrastructures of national importance. 

In this project, the researchers build a high accuracy model to predict the inflow and plant capacity as well as a model of plant equipment. Using features such as the water table / river levels and weather for the first model, and schematics/documentation and subject matter expertise for the second, the team trains a Reinforcement Learning (RL) agent to optimize plant operations by taking actions such as adjusting water flow rates and equalizing tank levels, based on predictions from the models as well real-time observations. For the Stage 2 Pilot, WAUTO will deployed at LPWRP through a phased approach as confidence in its performance improves. This civic-academic team consists of professionals from LPWRP, the Howard County Department of Public Works (DPW), researchers from APL and WSE, experts in geology and weather, and members from the broader community.

This project is in response to the Civic Innovation Challenge program’s Track A. Climate and Environmental Instability - Building Resilient Communities through Co-Design, Adaption, and Mitigation and is a collaboration between NSF, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory

por.por_cntn:
Extreme weather often affect local water plants, resulting in more water than wastewater treatment plants are able to handle. The Little Patuxent Water Reclamation Plant (LPWRP) in Howard County would like to address potential future challenges and ensure operational resilience through extreme weather events, a problem that is applicable nationally.  Specifically, we collaborate with LPWRP to design and implement a system, called WAUTO (Water operations AUTOmation), to optimize plant operations during extreme weather events.  During the planning grant stage, we worked closely with LPWRP and finally submitted a stage 2 proposal.  Specifically, we obtained additional data from LPWRP and trained a learning model for water level prediction. We hope to continue working LRWRP should the stage 2 proposal is advanced. 

 The broader impacts are that by taking a system thinking perspective around environmental thresholds when building WAUTO, the modular system developed could benefit resource constrained utilities with improved flow management during these events. In addition to improving the climate resilience of water utilities, the proposal is accompanied by an educational component to improve education in machine learning for critical infrastructure for graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 students through courses at Johns Hopkins University and internships at the Johns Hopkins University (JHU) Applied Physics Laboratory (APL). 

 


Last Modified: 04/03/2025
Modified by: Yinzhi Cao
